children.body: Must, on request, give access to personal information in an alternative format (if reasonable) to individuals with a sensory disability where they have a right to access their personal information

When carrying out public health sutides and research using personal data such must be processed exclusively within that entity, kept in a secure environment, anonymised or pseudonymised whenever possible and follow ethical standards for such studies. Disclosure of the results of the study mus…
Must be registered with the Registry of Data Controllers before processing data. The Registry is a publicly accessible register under the supervision of Data Protection Board
Third parties must not sell personal information sold to them without giving explicit notice to consumer and an opportunity to opt out
Businesses must not discriminate against consumers who exercise any of their privacy rights
Data concerning the exercise of a data subject's rights must not be used in a manner detrimental to that data subject
Must not process the resident registration number of a data subject
With only limited law enforcement/safety exceptions, no one must install and operate visual data processing devices so as to 'look into' usually private places (e.g. change rooms)

Any procedure whereby personal data collected for one or more purposes for 10 or more data subjects is compared with personal data collected for any other purpose and which may be used for taking any adverse action against any data subjects must only done with the consent of all relevant data subjects or the Commissioner
Specific requirements related to ISO/IEC 27001
The organization shall determine its role as either a PII controller or a PII processor
The organization shall include amongst its interested parties (see ISO/IEC 27001:2013 4.2), those parties having interests or responsibilities associated with PII processing
When determining the scope of the information security management system, the organization shall consider the explicit inclusion of the processing of PII

The organization shall establish, implement, maintain and continually improve a PII Management System (PIMS) in accordance with the requirements of ISO/IEC 27001 clauses 4 to 10, augmented by the requirements in clause 5 of this document

Compare the controls determined in 6.1.3 b) of ISO/IEC 27001:2013 with those in ISO/IEC 27001:2013, Annex A and with Annex A and B of this document to verify that no necessary controls have been omitted 
Produce a Statement of Applicability that contains:  − the necessary controls (see ISO/IEC 27001:2013, 6.1.3 b) and c));  − justification for their inclusion;  − whether the necessary controls are implemented or not; and  − the justification for excluding any of the controls in ISO/IEC 27001:2013, Annex A or Annex A and B of this document according to the organization's determination of its role (see 5.2.1)
Specific guidance related to ISO/IEC 27002
Information transfer policies and procedures
Confidentiality or non-disclosure agreements
Securing application services on public networks
Secure systems engineering principles
Supplier relationships
Management of information security incidents and improvements
Responsibilities and procedures
Response to information security incidents
Protection of records
Independent review of information security
Technical compliance review
Information security policies
Organization of information security
Human resource security
Classification of information
Management of removable media
Physical media transfer
User access management
User registration and de-registration
User access provisioning
Management of privileged access
Secure log-on procedures
Cryptography
Secure disposal or re-use of equipment
Clear desk and clear screen policy
Separation of development, testing and operational environments
Information backup
Event logging
Protection of log information
Guidance for PII controllers ⑦⑧⑩⑭
The organization should identify and document the specific purposes for which the PII will be processed
The organization should determine, document and comply with the lawful basis for the processing of PII for the identified purposes
The organization should determine and document a process for the demonstration of when and how consent is to be obtained from PII principals
The organization should obtain and record consent from PII principals according to the documented requirements
The organization should assess the need for a privacy impact assessment when a new or changed PII processing is planned
The organization should ensure that their contracts with PII processors address the implementation of the appropriate controls in Annex B
The organization should determine and maintain the necessary records in support of demonstrating compliance with its obligations for the processing of PII
The organization should ensure that the PII principals’ rights related to the processing of their PII are complied with, and provide the means to enable them to exercise their rights
The organization should identify and address any obligations, including legal obligations, to the PII principals resulting from decisions based solely on automated processing of PII.
The organization should determine and document the information which is to be provided to PII principals regarding the processing of their PII and the timing of such a provision
The organization should provide PII principals with clear and easily accessible information related to the PII controller and the processing of their PII
The organization should provide a mechanism for PII principals to modify or withdraw their consent.
The organization should provide a mechanism for PII principals to object to the processing of their PII

The organization should implement mechanisms to inform third parties with whom the PII has been shared of any modification, withdrawal or objections resulting from the exercising of PII principals' rights
The organization should implement mechanisms to facilitate the exercise of PII principals' rights to access, correct and/or erase their PII
The organization should be able to provide a copy of the PII that is being processed, subject to the retention and deletion policy, when requested by the PII principal.
The organization should have the means to handle the legitimate requests of PII principals.
PII controllers should limit the collection of PII to the minimum that is relevant, proportional and necessary for the identified purposes.
The organization should subject PII transmitted using a data-transmission network to appropriate controls designed to ensure that the data reaches its intended destination
The organization should limit the processing of PII to that which is adequate, relevant and necessary for the identified purposes.

The organization should define and document the need for the processing of PII without prior de-identification to achieve the identified purpose, or the extent to which the PII de-identification objectives are set, in such a way that the processing of the resulting de-identified PII is sufficient for the identified purpose.

The organization should identify and document the mechanisms by which data is processed in a timely manner in such a way that the extent to which the data can identify or be associated with PII principals meets the data minimization and de-identification objectives

The organization should either delete PII or render it in a form which does not permit identification of PII principals, as soon as the original PII is no longer necessary for the identified purpose(s)

The organization should ensure that temporary files and documents created as a result of PII processing are disposed of (e.g., erased or destroyed) following documented procedures within a specified, documented period
The organization should not retain PII for longer than necessary for the purpose(s) for which the PII is processed
The organization should have documented mechanisms for the disposal of PII
The organization should ensure that PII is as accurate, complete and up-to-date as is necessary for the purposes for which it is to be processed, throughout the life-cycle of the PII
The organization should identify and document the relevant basis for transfers of PII
The organization should specify and document the countries and international organizations to which PII might possibly be transferred
The organization should record transfers of PII to or from third parties and ensure cooperation with those parties to support exercise of future access rights to the PII principals
The organization should record disclosures of PII to third parties, including what PII has been disclosed, to whom and at what time
The organization should determine respective roles and responsibilities for PII processing (including security requirements) with any joint PII controller
Guidance for PII Processors ⑦⑧⑩⑭

The organization should ensure that the contract to process PII addresses (wherever relevant and taking into account the nature of processing and the information available to the organization) the organization’s role in providing assistance with the customer’s obligations as a PII controller
The organization should ensure that PII processed on behalf of a customer is not processed for any purpose independent of the documented instructions of the customer

The organization should not use PII processed under a contract for the purposes of marketing and advertising without express consent and not make providing such consent a condition for receiving the service
The organization should inform the PII controller and/or the customer if, in its opinion, a processing instruction infringes applicable legislation or regulation
The organization should provide a customer who is a PII controller with the information necessary for it to demonstrate compliance with its obligations

The organization should determine and maintain the necessary records in support of demonstrating compliance with its obligations for the processing of PII carried out on behalf of a customer who is a PII controller
The organization should provide the customer with the means to enable it to fulfil its obligation to facilitate the exercise of PII principals’ rights

The organization should ensure that temporary files and documents created as a result of PII processing are disposed of (e.g., erased or destroyed) following documented procedures within a specified, documented period

The organization should provide a capability for the return, transfer and/or disposal of PII and should make its policy for the exercise of this capability available to the customer before entering into a PII processing contract
The organization should subject PII transmitted using a data-transmission network to appropriate controls designed to ensure that the data reaches its intended destination

The organization should inform the customer in a timely manner of the basis for relevant PII transfers and of any intended changes in this regard so that the customer has the ability to object to such changes or to terminate the contract
The organization should specify and document the countries and international organizations to which PII might possibly be transferred
The organization should record disclosures of PII to third parties, including what PII has been disclosed, to whom and when
The organization should notify the customer of any legally binding requests for disclosure of PII, unless otherwise prohibited by law

The organization should reject any requests for PII disclosures that are not legally binding, consult the corresponding customer where legally permissible before making any PII disclosure and accept any contractually agreed requests for PII disclosures that are authorized by the corresponding customer
The organization should disclose any use of subcontractors to process PII to the relevant customer before use
The organization should provide a contractual undertaking not to engage a subcontractor to process PII outside of that described in the contract

The organization should, in the case of having general written authorization, inform the customer of any intended changes concerning the addition or replacement of subcontractors to process PII, thereby giving the customer the opportunity to object to such changes
Adoption, use or disclosure of government related identifiers: A private entity must not adopt or use a government related identifier of an individual as its own
Must take reasonable steps to implement practices, procedures and systems to ensure compliance with the APPs (APP 1.2)
A privacy policy must contain the kinds of personal information collected and held, how and for what purposes it is collected, held, used and disclosed (APP 1.4)

Must take steps to ensure personal information held is accurate, up-to-date and complete (APP 10) 
Must take steps to ensure personal information held is accurate, up-to-date and accurate (APP 10)
Must take reasonable steps to ensure personal information used or disclosed is up-to-date, complete and relevant (APP 10.2)
Must take reasonable steps to protect personal information held from misuse, interference and loss, unauthorised access, modification or disclosure (APP 11.1)

Must take reasonable steps to destroy or de-identify personal information once no longer needed for any purpose for which the information may be used or disclosed under the APPs and if not required to be retained by law (APP 11.2) 
Must take reasonable steps to destroy or de-identify personal information once no longer needed for any purpose for which the information may be used or disclosed under the APPs and if not required to be retained by law (APP 11.2)

Subject to any legal requirement to keep the information in an identifiable form 
Must take reasonable steps to destroy or ensure personal information is de-identified if the information is no longer needed for any purpose for which the information may be used or disclosed under the APPs and if it is not required to be retained by law
(APP 11.2) 
Must take reasonable steps to destroy or de-identify personal information once no longer needed for any purpose for which the information may be used or disclosed under the APPs and if not required to be retained by law
(APP 11.2)
Subject to any legal requirement to keep the information in an identifiable form

Must, on request, give access to the individual's personal information
(APP 12)

On request, an individual must be given access to their personal information
 (APP 12.1) 
On request, an individual must be given access to their personal information
(APP 12.1)
Must take steps to correct personal information and, if requested, notify third parties of the correction  (APP 13)

Must take reasonable steps to correct personal information of an individual if it is out-of-date, incomplete, irrelevant or misleading or if the individual requests it to be corrected
(APP 13.1)

Where personal information is disclosed and that information is subsequently corrected, if requested, reasonable steps must be taken to notify the recipient of the correction
(APP 13.2)
Where practicable individuals must have the option of not identifying themselves or using a pseudonym (APP 2)

Must not collect personal information unless the information is reasonably necessary for, or directly related to, the entity's functions or activities
(APP 3.2) 
Must not collect personal information unless it is reasonably necessary for the entity's functions or activities
(APP 3.2) 
Must not collect personal information unless the information is reasonably necessary for, or directly related to, the entity's functions or activities                 (APP 3.2)

Must not collect sensitive information unless consent is given and unless it is reasonably necessary for, or directly related to, the entity's functions or activities                                                             (APP 3.3) 
Must not collect sensitive information unless consent is given and unless it is reasonably necessary for, or directly related to, the entity's functions or activities
(APP 3.3) 
Must not collect sensitive information unless consent is given
 (APP 3.3)

Must determine if the  unsolicited personal information could have been solicited and, if not, delete or de-identify it
(APP 4) 
Must determine if the  unsolicited personal information could have been solicited and, if not, delete or de-identify it
 (APP 4)

Must notify certain matters on the collection of personal information
(APP 5) 
Must notify certain matters on the collection of personal information       (APP 5) 

This notification must be provided to the PII principals at or prior to the time of collecting the personal information or as soon as practicable thereafter
Must only use or disclose personal information as permitted under the APPs (e.g. as notified to individual at time of collection)                      (APP 6)

Personal information collected for a particular purpose must not be used or disclosed for another purpose unless consent is obtained (APP 6.1)

If testing is not an approved purpose, consent must be obtained 
Personal information  collected for a particular purpose must not be used or disclosed for another purpose unless consent is obtained (APP 6.1) 
Personal information  collected for a particular purpose must not be used or disclosed for another purpose unless consent is obtained
(APP 6.1)
If personal information is used or disclosed in accordance with APP 6.2(e) a written record of the use or disclosure must be kept (APP 6.5)
Unless an exception (e.g. consent) applies, must not use or disclose personal information for direct marketing (APP 7)
Before disclosing personal information to an overseas recipient, must take reasonable steps to ensure the overseas recipient does not breach the APPs (APP 8.1)

Must not do an act, or engage in a practice, that breaches an APP (S.15) 
Must not do an act, or engage in a practice, that breaches an APP (S.15)     

No processing of personal information contrary to the Privacy Act/APPs is permitted
Must carry out expeditious assessment of suspected eligible data breach (S.26WH)
Must prepare a statement about the eligible data breach and notify Privacy Commissioner (S.26WK)
Must notify eligible data breach to all affected individuals (S.26WL)
Privacy policy must include purposes for which the entity collects, holds and uses personal information (APP 1.4(c))

The privacy policy must set out how an individual may access their personal information and seek the correction of such
 (APP 1.4(d))

The privacy policy must include how an individual may complain about a breach of the APPs
(APP 1.4(e))

Must notify of any other person (or types of persons) to which the personal information is usually disclosed on collection of the personal information (APP 5.2(f))

This notification must be provided to the PII principals at or prior to the time of collecting the personal information or as soon as practicable thereafter 
Must notify of any other person (or types of persons) to which the personal information is usually disclosed on collection of the personal information (APP 5.2(f))
Must take reasonable steps to notify if personal information is to be disclosed to overseas recipients and the countries in which such recipients are likely to be located (APP 5.2(j))

Must notify of any other person (or types of persons) to which the personal information is usually disclosed on collection of the personal information
(APP 5.2(f))

This notification must be provided to the PII principals at or prior to the time of collecting the personal information or as soon as practicable thereafter
Every organisation must comply with the obligations (i.e. principles) in Schedule 1 (S.5(1))
Responsible for personal information under its control and must designate an individual(s) who are accountable for compliance (4.1)
Responsible for personal information that has been transferred to third parties for processing (4.1.3)
Must implement policies and practices to give effect to the principles (4.1.4)
An individual must be able to challenge compliance with principles (4.10)
The purposes for which personal information is collected must be identified at or before the time of collection (4.2)
Only personal information necessary for the identified purposes is to be collected (4.2.2)

Unless required by law, any use of personal information for a new purpose (i.e. not previously identified) must be consented to by the individual (4.2.4)

If testing is not an approved purpose, consent must be obtained
Must make reasonable efforts to ensure individuals are notified of purposes for which their personal information will be used (4.3.2)
The form of consent sought may vary depending on the type of information and circumstances (4.3.6)
Individuals can give consent in a manner of ways (4.3.7)
Individuals may withdraw consent at any time (4.3.8)
Collection of personal information is limited to that which is necessary for the identified purposes (4.4)
Personal information must not be used or disclosed for other than the purposes for which it was collected, except with the consent of the individual or as required by law (4.5)
Must develop guidelines and implement procedures with respect to retention of personal information (4.5.2)

Personal information no longer required for the identified purposes should be destroyed, erased or made anonymous (4.5.3) 
Personal information no longer required for the identified purposes should be destroyed, erased or made anonymous (4.5.3)

The nature of safeguards will vary depending on the sensitivity of the information and the format and method of storage of the information (4.7.2) 
Personal information no longer required for the identified purposes should be destroyed, erased or made anonymous (4.5.3)

Subject to any legal requirement to keep the information in an identifiable form
Personal information must be accurate, complete and up-to-date (4.6)
Personal information must be protected by appropriate security safeguards (4.7)

The nature of safeguards will vary depending on the sensitivity of the information and the format and method of storage of the information (4.7.2) 
The nature of safeguards will vary depending on the sensitivity of the information and the format and method of storage of the information (4.7.2)

Subject to any legal requirement to keep the information in an identifiable form
Must make employees aware of the importance of confidentiality of personal information (4.7.4)
Care must be used in the disposal or destruction of personal information (4.7.8)

Must make readily available information about its policies and practices relating to management of personal information (4.8) 
Personal information must be protected by appropriate security safeguards (4.8)

On request, must inform the individual of the existence, use and disclosure of his/her personal information and give access to it (4.9) 
Personal information must be protected by appropriate security safeguards (4.9)
Must amend the personal information held once individual demonstrates it is inaccurate or incomplete and, where appropriate, notify third parties of the amendment (4.9.5)
Must report to the Commissioner (S.10.1) ⑨
The data user must adopt contractual or other means to ensure data processors take appropriate security measures (DDP 4)

Must take all practical steps to inform a number of matters including the purpose of collection, the classes of persons who will have access to the information and rights to access and correct information and the contact information to whom such a request should be made (DPP 1) 
Must take all practical steps to inform a number of matters including the purpose of collection, the classes of persons who will have access to the information and rights to access and correct information and the contact information to whom such a request should be made (DPP 1)

Notification must be done on or before collection. 
Personal data must only be collected for a lawful purpose directly related to a function or activity of the data user, if adequate, not excessive and necessary for or directly related to the purposes for collection (DPP 1)

The data user must adopt contractual or other means to prevent data from being kept by data processors longer than necessary (DPP 2) 
Must take all practical steps to ensure personal data is not kept longer than necessary to fulfil the purpose for which it was collected (DPP 2) 
Must take all practical steps to ensure personal data is accurate having regard to the purposes for which it is or is to be used (DPP 2) 
Data user must adopt contractual provisions to prevent personal data being kept longer by data processor than necessary to fulfil the processing (DPP 2)

Personal data must not be used for a new purpose (i.e. not previously identified) unless the  consent of the data subject is obtained (DPP 3)

If testing is not an approved purpose, consent must be obtained
Must take all practical steps to ensure personal data is protected against unauthorised or accidental access, processing, erasure, loss or use (DPP 4)
Must take all practical steps to ensure that person can ascertain a data user's policies and practices in relation to personal data (DPP 5)
A data subject is entitled to ascertain whether personal data is held about them, request access to and correction of it (DPP 6)
An individual may make a request to be informed whether personal data is held in relation to the individual and to be supplied with a copy of such data (S.18)
On request by the individual, must correct personal data (S.22)
Must take all practicable steps to supply the third party with a copy of the corrected data (disclosed within prior 12 months) and a notice in writing stating the reasons for the correction (S.23)
Must take all practicable steps to erase data held where the data is no longer required for the purpose for which the data was used (S.26)
Matching procedures cannot be undertaken without the consent of all relevant data subjects or the Commissioner (S.30)
Must not use personal data for marketing without data subject's consent (S.35E)
Must cease using personal data for direct marketing when the data subject requests (S.35G)
A data user must not act or engage in practice that contravenes the data protection principles (S.4)

Except for Ss.24-25, no obligations apply to a 'data intermediary' in respect of its processing of personal data on behalf of and for the purposes of another organisation pursuant to a written contract (S.4(2)) ⑫ 
The personal data protection obligations do not apply to a data intermediary in respect of its processing of personal data on behalf of and for the purposes of another organisation pursuant to a written contract (S.4(2))
Organisations have the same obligations in respect of personal data processed for them by a 'data intermediary' as if it was processed by them (S.4(3))
Organisations are  responsible for the protection of personal data in their possession or under their control (S.11)
Must develop and implement policies, practices and processes to meet data protection obligations and receive and respond to complaints (S.12)
Unless permitted by law, collection, use and/or disclosure of personal data requires the individual's consent to that collection, use and disclosure (S.13)
On reasonable notice an individual may withdraw any consent given or deemed to be given (S.16)

Collection, use and/or disclosure of personal data must be reasonable in the circumstances and the individual must be informed of the purposes for collection, use and disclosure (S.18)

If testing is not an approved purpose, consent must be obtained

Must inform the individual of the purposes for collection, use and/or disclosure of personal data (S.20) 
Must inform the individual of the purposes for collection, use and/or disclosure of personal data (S.20)

Notification must be done on or before collection.
On request must, as soon as reasonably possible provide the personal data about that individual in the organisation's possession or under its control (S.21)

On request must, as soon as practical, correct an error or omission in the personal data (in possession or under your control) unless satisfied on reasonable grounds that the correction should not be made and send the correct information to every other organisation to which the personal data was disclosed in the past year  (S.22)
If personal data is likely to be used to make decisions affecting the individual, must make reasonable efforts to ensure that the personal data is accurate and complete (S.23)

Must make reasonable security arrangements to prevent unauthorised access, collection, use, disclosure, copying, modification, disposal or similar risks for personal data held or under their control (S.24)

Must delete or de-identify documents containing personal data as soon as it is reasonable to assume that the purpose for which the personal data was collected is no longer being served and retention is no longer necessary for legal or business purposes (S.25)

Subject to any legal requirement to keep the information in an identifiable form
May only transfer personal data outside Singapore in accordance with the requirements of the Act (S.26)

Must inform the individual of specified matters including the purposes for the collection and use of the personal information (A.15) 
Must inform the individual of specified matters including the purposes for the collection and use of the personal information (A.15)

Notification must be done on or before collection.

Must collect only the minimum personal information necessary for the purposes. Where more personal information than this is collected you must expressly inform the individual so that they can deny consent (A.16)
May only disclose personal information where the individual has consented to disclosure for the relevant purposes (A.17)

Must not use personal information or disclose it to another entity for purposes other than those consented to/otherwise permitted with  additional consent provided by the individual (A.18)

If testing is not an approved purpose, consent must be obtained

A recipient of personal information cannot use it or disclose it for any other purpose, except as permitted for by law or where additional consent is provided by the individual (A.19) 
A recipient of personal information cannot use it or disclose it for any other purpose, except as permitted by law or additional consent is provided by the individual (A.19) 
A recipient of personal information cannot use it or disclose it for any other purpose, except as permitted by law or where additional consent is provided by the individual (A.19)

Once the retention period has expired or the purpose has been fulfilled, must destroy the personal information without delay (unless retention is required by law)  (A.21) 
Once the retention period has expired or the purpose has been fulfilled, must destroy the personal information without delay (unless retention is required by law)  (A.21)

Subject to any legal requirement to keep the information in an identifiable form 
Once the retention period has expired or the purpose has been fulfilled, must destroy the personal information without delay (unless retention is required by law) (A.21)

Subject to any legal requirement to keep the information in an identifiable form
When obtaining consent, must present the request in a clear manner, including setting out each matter requiring consent separately and getting consent for each of those matters (A.22)
Must not process sensitive information except where individual consents to processing or where the law permits it (A.23)

On outsourcing the processing of personal information to a third party, must satisfy certain formalities in writing and prevent processing for purposes other than the purposes for which the processing was outsourced and ensure technical and managerial safeguards (A.26)
Must educate and supervise those employees who carry out the processing of personal information (A.28)
Must take such technical, managerial, and physical measures (e.g. management plans and access logs) to ensure the protection of personal information (A.29)
Must comply with the Personal Information Protection Principles (A.3)

Must have a privacy policy that sets out specified matters including the purposes for which personal information is processed, any disclosures of personal information, rights and obligations of data subjects and how to exercise those rights (A.30)
Where a potential breach of personal information is highly probably should make efforts to carry out a privacy impact assessment (A.33)

Must notify individuals affected by a data breach of the personal information divulged, when and how it was divulged, how to minimise the risk of harm, remedial action being taken and contact details for a helpdesk for the reporting of damage (A.34)
The data subject may demand access to his/her own personal information, which is processed by the personal information processor (A.35)
Must publish directions for how to exercise rights (A.38)
Data subjects have specified rights in relation to the process of his/her personal data (A.4)
The obligations, principles and procedures under the law are binding on all who process personal data (A.1)

Must notify certain matters on the collection of personal information (A.10) 
Must inform data subjects of a number of matters including purposes of processing (A.10) 
Must notify certain matters on the collection of personal information (A.10)

This notification must be provided at or prior to the time of collecting the personal information or as soon as practicable thereafter.
Must take reasonable steps to notify to whom personal data might be transferred and the purposes for same (A.10.1)
Must take reasonable steps to notify to whom processed personal data might be transferred and the purposes for the same (A.10.1.c)

Upon request must notify third parties of (i) rectification in cases of  incomplete or inaccurate data and/or (ii) deletion or destruction of personal data (A.11) 
Must take actions, if requested regarding (i) rectification in case personal data are processed incompletely or inaccurately; (ii) deletion or destruction of personal data (iii) notification of the operations made  to third parties to whom personal data have been transferred (A.11)
Data subject may object to processing of personal data exclusively through automated systems (A.11.1.g)

Must take all necessary technical and administrative measures to provide a sufficient level of security in order to (i) prevent unlawful processing of personal data, (ii) prevent unlawful access to personal data, and (iii) ensure the retention of personal data (A.12.1) 
Must take all necessary technical and administrative measures to provide a sufficient level of security in order to (i) prevent unlawful processing of personal data, (ii) prevent unlawful access to personal data, and (iii) ensure the retention of personal data (A.12.1)

Jointly responsible with processor to take all necessary technical and administrative measures to provide a sufficient level of security in order to (i) prevent unlawful processing of personal data, (ii) prevent unlawful access to personal data, and (iii) ensure the retention of personal data (A.12.2)
Must conduct necessary inspections in order to ensure compliance (A.12.3)
Must notify the data subject and the  Personal Data Protection Board of data breaches within the shortest time (A.12.5)

The data subject may lodge his/her demands under and object regarding implementation of the law with the controller who must act on them in the shortest time possible (A.13) 
The data subject may lodge his/her demands under and objects regarding implementation of the law with the controller who must act on them in the shortest time possible (A.13)

Personal data may only be processed; (i) for specific, explicit and legitimate purposes, (ii) being relevant with, limited to and proportionate to the purposes for which they are processed. (A.4.2)  
Personal data may only be processed; (i) for specific, explicit and legitimate purposes, (ii) being relevant with, limited to and proportionate to the purposes for which they are processed (A.4.2)  
Data processing must be relevant, limited and proportionate to the purposes for which data is to be processed (A.4.2) 
Personal data processed must be accurate and if necessary, up to date (A.4.2)

Personal data may only be processed; (i) for specific, explicit and legitimate purposes, (ii) being relevant with, limited to and proportionate to the purposes for which they are processed (A.4.2.c)

If testing is not an approved purpose, consent must be obtained 
Personal data may only be processed for specific, explicit and legitimate purposes (A.4.2.c)
Personal data cannot be processed without the explicit consent of the data subject unless the one of legitimate purposes exists (A.5.2)
Unless specifically permitted by law, it is prohibited to process the personal data of "special nature" without explicit consent (A.6.2)

Personal data must be deleted, destroyed or anonymised on request by the data subject or when  the reasons necessitating its processing cease to exist (A.7) 
Personal data must be deleted, destroyed or anonymised upon request by the data subject or when  the reasons necessitating its processing cease to exist (A.7)
Unless approved conditions apply, personal data cannot be transferred without explicit consent of the data subject (A.8)

Personal data may only be transferred abroad without explicit consent if (i) sufficient protection is provided in the foreign country where the data is to be transferred, or (ii) the data controller in Turkey and in the related foreign country guarantee a sufficient protection in writing and the Data Protection Board has authorized such transfer, where sufficient protection is not provided. (A.9.2) 
Personal data may only be transferred abroad without explicit consent if (i) sufficient protection is provided in the foreign country where the data is to be transferred, or (ii) the data controller in Turkey and in the related foreign country must guarantee a sufficient protection in writing and the Data Protection Board has authorized such transfer, where sufficient protection is not provided (A.9.2)

Implied by S.1798.150 – civil action possible in respect of unauthorised access to personal information as a result of violation of the duty to implement and maintain reasonable security procedures and practices (S.1798.150(a) ⑯

Implied by S.1798.150 – civil action possible in respect of unauthorised access to personal information as a result of violation of the duty to implement and maintain reasonable security procedures and practices (S.1798.150(a)) ⑮ 
Must document the consumer’s rights and how to exercise them/make a request (S.1798.130(a)) 
Ensure all those responsible for handling consumer privacy inquiries and compliance are informed of all requirements under Ss.1798.120 and 1798.135 (S.1798.135(a)) 
Must provide a clear and conspicuous link on the business’ Internet homepage titled “Do Not Sell My Personal Information” to allow consumers to opt-out of the sale of personal information (S.1798.135 (a))

Must not use personal information for additional purposes beyond those notified (S.1798.100(b)) 
Must not use personal information for additional purposes beyond those notified (S.1798.100(b))

If testing is not a notified purpose, consent must be obtained 
Must inform at or prior to collection as to the categories of personal information collected and purposes for which such will be used (S.1798.100(a) and (b)) 
Must disclose categories of personal information the business sells and the categories of third parties to whom sold (S.1798.115(a) and (b)) 
Must not collect additional categories of personal information beyond those notified (S.1798.100(b)) 
Must disclose details of the categories of third parties to whom the personal information is sold (S.1798.115(a) and (b))

Must not sell (a) a consumer’s personal information after a request not to sell and (b) a minor’s personal information unless an appropriate consent is obtained (S.1798.120(c)) 
Must delete personal information on request of consumer and direct service providers (to whom such was provided) to delete such personal information (S.1798.105(c)) 
Must disclose details of the categories of third parties with whom the personal information is shared (S.1798.110(b) and (c))

Use of personal information must be reasonably necessary and proportionate to achieve the purpose for which it was collected (S.1798.140(d)) 
Must not sell the personal information of consumers less than 16 years of age unless appropriate consent/authorisation is obtained (S.1798.120(c) and (d)) 
Must, on request, give access to the consumer’s personal information (S.1798.100(d))

A business is not liable for the personal information disclosed to a service provider who uses it in violation of the CCPA, provided the business follows the requirements of the CCPA and has no knowledge or reasonable belief of any intention to commit such a violation. A service provider is likewise not liable for the compliance of a business with the CCPA (S.1798.145(h)) ⑭ 
Businesses disclosing personal information to service providers, with knowledge or a reason to believe the service provider intends to violate the restrictions imposed by the provisions, will be liable for such violations (S.1798.145(h))

Must only disclose personal information to a service provider pursuant to a written contract that prohibits processing of the personal information for any purpose other than performing the specified services (S.1798.140 (v) and (w))
The controller's legitimate interest can, among other things, only justify processing of personal data strictly necessary for the intended and transparent purpose of the controller (Art 10)

Processing of sensitive personal data must only occur with consent or if indispensable for, among others, compliance with a legal obligation or protecting life or physical safety or protection health (Art 11)
Processing of childrens' personal data must be with consent of at least one parent or the legal representative (Art 14)

Personal data must be deleted once processing complete or terminated, except in compliance with legal obligations or in anonymised form for exclusive use of controller (Art 16)

Subject to any legal requirement to keep the information in an identifiable form

Data subjects have rights to obtain, among others, confirmation of the processing, access to data, correction of data, anonymisation, portability of data, deletion, withdrawal revocation of consent (Art 18)

Confirmation of existence of and access to personal data must be provided in a simple format immediately and by means of a clear and complete notice of processing within 15 days of request (Art 19) 
Confirmation of existence of and access to personal data must be provided in a simple format immediately and by means of a clear and complete notice of processing with 15 days of request (Art 19)
Data subject has the right to request review of decisions taken solely by automated processing of personal data (Art 20)

International transfer of personal data is only allowed, among others, to countries with a similar level of protection, when the controller offers (and proves) guarantees of compliance with principles and protections in the law (Art 33)
Controllers and processors must keep records of personal data processing operations (Art 37)
The regulator may require a controller to prepare an impact report on their processing of personal data (Art 38)
The processor must carry out processing according to the controller's instructions (Art 39)
Must appoint a DPO to be in charge of processing personal data and a point of contact and must publicly disclose DPO's identity and contact details (Art 41)

Must adopt security, technical and administrative measures to protect personal data from unauthorised access and accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, communication or processing (Art 46)
Must communicate to regulator and data subjects the occurrence of a security incident and include certain minimum information (Art 48)
The systems used for processing personal data must be structured to meet security requirements, standards of good practice and governance and general principles under the law (Art 49)

Processing of personal data activities must be in good faith and, among others, be for notified purpose(s), necessary and transparent (Art 6) 
Processing of personal data activities must be in good faith and, among others, be for notified purpose(s), necessary and transparent (Art 6)

If testing is not an approved purpose, consent must be obtained

Processing of personal data must only be carried out, among others, with the consent of the data subject, for compliance with a legal obligation, when necessary for execution of a contract, for protection of life, physical security or to protect health, protection of credit or when necessary to fulfil the controller's legitimate interests (Art 7)

The consent required in Art 7 must be given in writing or other means that shows the consent of the data subject (Art 8) 
Consent may be revoked at any time by express request via a free of charge procedure (Art 8)
Specified information concerning the processing of the data subject's personal data must be made available in a clear transparent manner to the data subject (Art 9)
